awd_titl_txt: Theoretical and Experimental Studies of Auroral Farley-Buneman Waves
awd_abstract_narration:
Farley-Buneman (FB) wave instability is triggered in a partially ionized plasma when a cross-field drift of electrons relative to ions exceeds a critical threshold value. This phenomenon substantially modifies current flows, and thus affects the response of the entire Magnetosphere-Ionosphere (MI) system, primarily during storm-time. FB waves also produce strong radar echoes, and these allow monitoring of the MI system. The original theory of FB waves is based on linear, local fluid theory that does not account for many observed aspects of the waves. The results of the work would improve understanding of MI coupling not only though the modification of models of this coupling, but also through the diagnostic use of the radar echoes produced by FB waves. The project will fund a graduate student and engage Master's and undergraduate students in space research.

The Principal Investigators (PIs) will synthesize improved theory, nonlinear numerical simulation, and numerous disparate observations, including measurements from the High Frequency Active Auroral Research Program (HAARP) heater. The project will implement a new approach to radar imaging using "compressive sensing."  This technique has been transformative in other fields, and is seen as potentially beneficial to the Coupling, Energetics and Dynamics of Atmospheric Regions (CEDAR) radio science community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Since their discovery more than fifty years ago, radars, rockets, and numerical simulations have answered numerous questions about the dynamics of Farley-Buneman (FB) instabilities.These instabilities produce irregularities in the auroral E-region ionosphere which both modify the background ionosphere and magnetospehere in complicated ways and serve as a source of radar and radio clutter, potentially interfering with operational radio communication, navigation, and imaging systems. FB waves pose both interesting theoretical and important practical problems.

Part of our work involves observing Farley Buneman waves using a VHF coherent scatter radar imager deployed in Alaska. The radar uses aperture-synthesis imaging techniques to form images of the radio aurora. A component of the project involved updating our imaging methods by incorporating methods rooted in compressive sensing, a contemporary method of image processing. As the radar can observe irregularities created artificially by the NSF-supported ionopspheric modification facility in Gakona, Alaska, part of our work involved studying the artificial irregularities. We quantified transport and dissipation mechanisms at work in the artificial irregularities by measuring their onset threshold, informing our research on natural FB instabilities.

The balance of our research was computational. Considerable progress in recent years has been made in modeling FB waves using particle-in-cell (PIC) methods.  Although pic simulations have been able to model many aspects of the nonlinear physics of FB instabilities, their application to non-local scales has been challenging due to the computational cost. This difficulty has motivated the exploration of more cost-effective approaches. Work performed throughout the award period developed a numerical framework based on the five-moment fluid model to simulate FB instabilities and evaluate its ability to reproduce nonlinear features reported from PIC simulations.

For the theoretical part of our work, we continued investigating the stability features of our fluid solver developed early in the award. First, we explored the role of viscosity in weakly ionized plasmas. We drew from the literature on solar atmospheres to construct proper viscosity terms that may have the potential to damp small-scale turbulence to get closer to the power spectra produced by full kinetic solvers. Similarly, we identified new theoretical work on Landau fluid closures that extend the Hammett-Perkins operator we used in the past for collisionally dominated ions. The new fluid closures are easier to implement and, combined with the viscosity terms, may capture most of the damping reported in kinetic simulations. Finally, we identified a limitation in the artificial electron mass assumption. Previous FB kinetic simulations have used artificially large electron mass while preserving the mobility and magnetization parameters by reducing the electron-neutral collision frequency. This approximation does not hold when electron inertia is considered.

We demonstrated that the proposed, simplified fluid models could produce most of the characteristic nonlinear features of FB waves, even when removing the viscosity term from the five-moment system. This last result suggested that the proposed fluid framework may significantly increase the scalability of FB simulations. Our findings have significant implications for the plasma and space physics communities as they may open the door for other researchers to explore this topic using fluid plasma models.
